title: Anna Mika's photography shows abandoned buildings before nature reclaims them

It resembles a scene from a horror film.
Ghostly, hooded figures lurk in an old, crumbling church. But all is not what it seems. They are merely sculptures and this photograph of them is one of many by photographer Anna Mika of abandoned European buildings.
While many would think twice before stepping foot into eerie, crumbling factories or decaying medical centres, photographer Anna Mika chooses to explore them to discover their subtle allure.
Eerie surroundings: One of photographer Anna Mika's most haunting shots is that of the decrepit 14th century St George's church in Lukova, Czech Republic, which features ghostly hooded figures hunched over pews or walking down the aisles
Her work on abandoned locations features sites that will soon be reclaimed by nature, such as this abandoned church in Poland
Colourful beauty: Light streams through a patterned stained-glass window in a forgotten orthodox church in Poland
The plucky 25-year-old from Poland's mysterious collection is called Urbex - Urban Exploration - and features mines, factories and hospitals.
Through her project Mika hopes to look past the exteriors of forgotten buildings, and to discover a side to them no one else has appreciated.
One of her most haunting shots is that of the decrepit 14th century St George's church in Lukova, Czech Republic, which features ghostly, hooded figures hunched over pews or walking down the aisles.
According to Mika, the sculptures were placed there by an artist, in a bid to save the church from ruin.
The spooky figures have resulted in a boost in visitors to the village church and the donations they make are being used for much-needed repairs.

Surprisingly, Mika admitted she has a fear of the dark and spiders, two elements which she has to battle to take her images.
'Sometimes it is hard but I would do almost anything for the images,' she said. 'I travel with my friends and my boyfriend and some places don't have an owner so I don't need permission to go straight in.'
School's out: A blackboard has started to peel off the wall, still covered in writing, at an old school in France
A hat and a chair still remain at a derelict German power station, with marks of graffiti visible on the old controls machine
A dilapidated piano is pictured keeled over, in a crumbling atrium in an old Polish palace, captured by the 25-year-old photographer
Winding staircase: Mika explored down an old stairwell of a decaying palace in Poland
Her favourite image was the first one she took in the project, that of a derelict cement plant in Jaworzno.
She said: 'I instantly fell in love with the place. Since then Iâ€™ve been trying to visit as many abandoned places as possible, in Poland and other countries.
'There is something enticing about abandoned places. One can feel the past in such places, they have a peculiar smell. The nature is inevitably reclaiming them.'
The talented photographer started taking photographs when she was in school, at the time using an analog camera and her bathroom as a dark room for developing.
Chilling: Smashed glass allowed an unobstructed view into an old hospital in Poland, with tiles lying strewn on the floor

She now has a varied portfolio, but enjoys bringing people's attention to decaying urban destinations before they are fully destroyed.
'People forget their history and old places,' she said. 'Everyone is looking for something new, new connections, gadgets, relationships and I think it is worth reminding others where they come from, reminding them of the history of their cities, factories and coal mines.
'These places are still beautiful even if they are almost gone.'
